title: Collaborative Top Distribution Identifications with Limited InteractionAccepted for presentation at the 61st Annual IEEE Symposium on Foundations of Computer Science (FOCS 2020). Nikolai Karpov and Qin Zhang are supported in part by NSF IIS-1633215, CCF-1844234 and CCF-2006591. Yuan Zhou is supported in part by NSF CCF-2006526 and a JPMorgan Chase AI Research Faculty Research Award.
abstract:
Abstract
We consider the following problem in this paper: given a set of nùëõn distributions, find the top-mùëöm ones with the largest means. This problem is also called top-mùëöm arm identifications in the literature of reinforcement learning, and has numerous applications. We study the problem in the collaborative learning model where we have multiple agents who can draw samples from the nùëõn distributions in parallel. Our goal is to characterize the tradeoffs between the running time of learning process and the number of rounds of interaction between agents, which is very expensive in various scenarios.
We give optimal time-round tradeoffs, as well as demonstrate complexity separations between top-111 arm identification and top-mùëöm arm identifications for general mùëöm and between fixed-time and fixed-confidence variants. As a byproduct, we also give an algorithm for selecting the distribution with the mùëöm-th largest mean in the collaborative learning model.
